Civil Aviation (Question No. J030) Mr Dobie asked the Minister for Civil Aviation, upon notice: 1. Has his attention been drawn to a claim by a previous Labor Minister for Local Government in New South Wales that the original proposal for airport development on the Kurnell Peninsula area did not originate with his Government? 2. Is he able to say whether in several statements in tbe New South Wales Hansard this same Minister indicated that his Government had appointed a Committee to investigate this matter and later co-operated with the Commonwealth Departments regarding an examination of the proposal? able member's questions are as follows: 1. Yes. 2. The following extracts from the New South Wales' Hansard refer to tbe matter: (a) N.S.W. Hansard-18t h September 1963Page 5049 ment): 'Discussions are proceeding in connection Soulh Wales have always extended co-operation with the establishment of a second airport at Botany Bay. It is proposed that it should tial investigations which have been, and are being be located on the Kurnell peninsula. A committee has been appointed by the Government under the chairmanship of an officer of my department, to investigate the matter, and the Maritime Services Board and the Minister for Lands have representatives on it.' (another extract from page 5049) This is not a new scheme. It has been talked about for twenty years. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition interjects that it is not a new scheme. The Government knows it, for in the 1940s a question was raised whether the airport at Mascot should be expanded to its present extent, or whether another should be developed at the place I have mentioned.' (b) N.S.W. Hansard-22n d October 1963Page 5811 Extract'As far as I knew, that was where the matter rested. The extraction of sand from the north-eastern corner which is probably a mile and a half distant from the southwestern corner is unlikely to have any effect upon activities at an airport. It is not expected that the reduction of the elevation of the ground will have an adverse effect upon the approaches to the airport. Therefore I do not think I need elaborate. speaker: 1,345 1,438 1,464 I.4s4 1.597 Mr Gorton
theText: The answer to the honour4. Were the items quoted by him numbered (2) and (3) of paragraph 9, and do they appear on page 7 of the Keport? 5. Do paragraphs 11 to 20 commence on page 7 of the Report and continue to page 10? 6. Do these paragraphs record many allegations and findings such as: (a) the conclusion of a bilateral military agreement between President Ngo Dinh Diem and United States Ambassador Nolting: (b) the gradual introduction of about 5,000 United States military personnel into South Vietnam, wbich would soon be increased to 8,000; (c) the arrival of four aircraft carriers-'Core' , 'Breton', 'Princeton' and 'Croaton'-o n different occasions, bringing in helicopters, other aircraft, military equipment and military personnel; (d) the introduction by the United States of America of approximately four companies of helicopters, many jet fighters, fighters/ fighter bombers and transport planes, along with military vehicles and other stores; (e) the visits of a large number of high United States military experts and dignitaries to Saigon for inspection and guidance, particularly those of General Maxwell Taylor, Admiral H. Felt and General Lemnitzer; (f) the establishment of a United States Military Assistance Command, with a four-star General, Paul D. Harkins, as its Chief; (g) the denial of the right of the Commission's Teams in South Vietnam to control and inspect, which was part of their mandatory tasks, and to determine precisely the quantum and nature of war materials unloaded and introduced into South Vietnam; (h) the flagrant violation of the Geneva Agreement by the Government of the Republic of Vietnam in requesting the Government of the United States of America to intensify the aid in personnel and material which the latter was already granting to Vietnam; (i) the violations of Article 17 (e) and Article 25 recorded against the Republic of Vietnam for its failure to notify arrivals and imports, and for not affording all possible assistance to the Commission's Teams in the performance of their tasks: and (j) the violation of Articles 16 and 17 by the Republic of Vietnam in receiving increased military aid from the United States of America in the absence of any established credit in its favour, and the establishment of a United States Military Assistance Command in South Vietnam which amounted to a factual military alliance which was prohibited under Article 19 of the Agreement? 7. Does the statement of only items (2) and (3) and the omission of any mention of paragraphs 11 to 20 give a complete and accurate view of the Special Report's conclusions? 8. Does the United States State Department publication 'Aggression from the North' published in February 1965, give prominence also to items (2) and (3), as he did, and omit mention of the Commission's findings against South Vietnam and the United States in paragraph 11 to 20? 9. l f so, does the publication 'Aggression from the North' give a complete and accurate view of the conclusions of the International Commission for Supervision and Control about the movement of men, arms and material upon which it was reporting in the Special Report of 2nd June 1962? able member's questions are as follows: 1. Yes. 2. Yes. 3. No. The honourable member's question implies that lhe Special Report contains conclusions about aggression by North and South Vietnam against each other. The Report does not make any such statement; neither did I . My central point is that the Special Report to the Co-Chairman of the Geneva Conference on Indo-China of 2nd June contains evidence that the zone in the North had been used as a base for aggression against the Armed Forces and Administration of the Zone in the South. This can be seen from paragraph 9 (2) and paragraph 10 of the Report. Paragraph 9 (2) gives the Legal Committee's conclusion 'that armed and unarmed personnel, arms, munitions and other supplies have been sent from the Zone in the North to the Zone in the South with the object of supporting, organising and carrying out hostile activities, including armed attacks directed against the Armed Forces and Administration of the Zone in the South'. This finding was accepted by the Commission at paragraph 10. 4. The items appear on page 7 of Cmnd. 1755, as follows: '(2) Having examined the complaints and the supporting materia] sent by the South Vietnamese Mission, the Committee has come to the conclusion that in specific instances there is evidence to show that armed and unarmed personnel, arms, munitions and other supplies have been sent from the Zone in the North to the Zone in the South with the object of supporting, organising and carrying out hostile activities, including armed attacks, directed against the Armed Forces and Administration of the Zone in the South. These acts are in violation of Articles 10, 19, 24 and 27 of the Agreement on the Cessation of Hostilities in Vietnam. (3) In examining the complaints and the supporting material, in particular documentary material sent by the South Vietnamese Mission, the Committee has come to the further conclusion that there is evidence to show that the PAVN has allowed the Zone in the North to be used for inciting, encouraging and supporting hostile activities in the Zone in the South, aimed at the overthrow of the Administration in the South. The use of the Zone in the North for such activities is in violation of Articles 19, 24 and 27 of the Agreement on the Cessation of Hostilities in Vietnam'. 5. Paragraphs 11 to 20 begin on page 7 of Cmnd. 1755 and continue to page 10. 6. (a) to (f) These are North Vietnamese allegations which are recorded as such in paragraph 11 of the Report: (g) The Report includes the Commission's view to this effect.

The already granting to Vietnam". This is an extract from a communication addressed to the Commission on 9th December 1961 by the Liaison Mission of the Republic of Vietnam. (i) to (j) Pages 8, 9 and 10 of Cmnd. 1755 refer. 7, 8 and 9. My statement included references to the material in paragraphs 11 to 20 of the Report. Paragraphs 9 (2) and 9 (3) contained conclusions of the Legal Committee. The Commission accepted these conclusions, and 'Aggression from the North', at Appendix A, page 30, not only refers to paragraph 9 (2) and 9 (3) but correctly cites paragrapn 10 of the Commission's findings as follows: "The Commission accepts the conclusions reached by the Legal Committee that there is sufficient evidence to show beyond reasonable doubt that the PAVN has violated Articles 10, 19, 24 and 27 in specific instances. The Polish Delegation dissents from these conclusions. On the basis of the fuller report, that is being prepared by the Legal Committee covering all the allegations and incidents, the Commission will take action as appropriate in each individual case.' Readers are then referred to the full text of the ICC Report contained in a publication, 'Special Report to the Co-Chairmen of the Geneva Conference on Indo-China', issued by the Bureau of Far Eastern Affairs of the Department of State on 2nd July 1962. Fires in Commonwealth Establishments (Question No. 984) Mr Whitlam asked the Prime Minister, upon notice: 1. DidI ask him on notice on 5th June what majorfires,other than that in the Melbourne Mail Exchange in November 1967, had broken out in Commonwealth establishments in the last 5 years? 2. Did he in an answer on 19th September (Hansard, page 1357) provide me with the information from the Minister for Works that during the past 5 years only two fires other than the Mail Exchange fire caused damage in excess of $100,000 to Commonwealth property? 3. Was one of them the $1,600,000 fire at HMAS Albatross last Christmas? 4. When and where was the other fire, and what damage did it cause? able member's questions are as follows: 1. Ves. 2. Yes. 3. No. The Minister for Works has advised that the only two reports received by the Commonwealth Fire Board of fire damage to CommonThe report received by the Commonwealth Fire damage 'undeclared'. The hut in which the fire originated was stated to be of the value of $8,000, and the valuable equipment destroyed, accounting total value of the damage to the hut and equipment, $1,600,000, was not brought to the notice of the Commonwealth Fire Board until the publication of the Auditor-General's report. 4. Thefiresreferred to were: (i) At the Weapons Research Establishment, Woomera, in 1967-exten t of damage estimated at $263,000. This was in the building occupied by Hawker de Havilland Co., and additional damage was caused to their property. (ii) At the Army Signals Training Centre, Westgarth, Victoria in 1963-estimate d damage $230,000. Subsidies to Industries (Question No. 1041) Mr Charles Jones asked the Treasurer, upon notice: 1. Does the Commonwealth pay a subsidy to some Australian primary and secondary industries? 2. If so, (a) what are the industries, (b) when was the subsidy granted in each instance and (c) what payments have been made to each industry since 1939-40? honourable member's questions is as follows: I refer the honourable member to the answers provided to similar questions previously asked by him and which appear in Hansards of 30th October 1963 and 16th September 1965. Information on Commonwealth payments to industry in recent years can be found in Item No. 10 of Statement No. 2 attached to my Budget Speech of 13th August 1968 and printed in Hansard on that day. Shipping (Question No. 1042) Mr Charles Jones asked the Minister for Shipping and Transport, upon notice: Is he able to say which countries have (a) National and (b) Private shipping lines? able member's question is as follows: Precise details of the control of the Merchant Marine of all countries of the world are not readily available. In general terms, it can be taken that most maritime trading nations operate commercially with privately owned shipping. However, many of these nations also operate national shipping lines.

Drought Relief (Question No. 1064) Mr Munro asked the Treasurer, upon notice: Under the present arrangements by which the Commonwealth pays half the cost of any subsidies for the transport of fodder undertaken by the State Government of New South Wales in the drought-stricken areas of Eden-Monaro, in the event of a decision by the State Government to apply a subsidy of 40 cents per bushel on the transport of feed wheat or other grain, in addition upon notice: to the freight subsidies already available on fodder, would the Commonwealth pay half of the cost of this additional subsidy? honourable member's question is as follows: The Commonwealth has agreed to meet half the cost in this financial year of relief measures which the New South Wales Government may find it necessary to continue in the South Coast, Southern Tablelands and Cobar districts until the drought breaks. The relief measures for which the Commonwealth has agreed to contribute are those which have been applied in New South Wales drought areas during the past three years. They include the provision of loans for carry on purposes where credit is not available through normal commercial channels; rebates of freight on the transport of fodder and water to drought affected areas and the transport of starving stock out of drought areas; expenditure to provide relief work Port of registry Australian operator Martiques-French F. Pty Ltd for those unemployed in rural areas as a result of drought; and miscellaneous expenditure in relation to the drought, such as cloud seeding. In the case of rebates of freight on the transport of fodder to feed starving stock, the Commonwealth has agreed to meet half the cost of rebates of up to 75 per cent of the total transport cost by rail. Where rail transport is not available the Commonwealth will meet half the cost of rebates of similar proportions of road transport costs. However, the precise details of the subsidy arrangements to apply in any particular area are a matter for the State. On this basis, the Commonwealth would be prepared to meet half the cost of rebates of up to 75 per cent of the transport cost of feed wheat or otlier grain to feed starving stock in the South Coast and Southern Tablelands area. theText: The answer to the honourTaxation (Question No. 1072) Dr Everingham asked the Treasurer, upon notice: Will be consider recommending legislation to remove tax exemption from advertising of tobacco products and alcoholic drinks and to use resulting revenues in (a) advertising to young people the facts about the social and physiological significance carrying on a business to produce such income, of smoking and drinking; (b) alleviating hardship caused to any section of the tobacco or liquor industries by such legislation and (c) alleviating the burden on public revenue due to disease effects of tobacco or alcohol? honourable member's question is as follows: The primary purpose of the income tax law is to raise revenue for the Commonwealth. It is a well-established principle of the law that expenses which are incurred in gaining or producing assessable income or which are necessarily incurred in should be allowed as deductions for income tax purposes. It is not considered appropriate to depart from those principles for a purpose which is quite unrelated to the taxation of income.
